heading: Description
value: Images, form image buttons, and image map hot spots have appropriate, equivalent alternative text.

heading: Description
value: Images that do not convey content, are decorative, or contain content that is already conveyed in text are given empty alternative text (alt="") or implemented as CSS backgrounds. All linked images have descriptive alternative text.

heading: Description
value: Equivalent alternatives to complex images are provided in context or on a separate linked page.

heading: Description
value: Form buttons have a descriptive value.

heading: Description
value: Form inputs have associated text labels.

heading: Description
value: Embedded multimedia is identified via accessible text.

heading: Description
value: Frames and iframes are appropriately titled.

heading: Description
value: Semantic markup is used to designate headings (<h1>), regions/landmarks, lists (<ul>, <ol>, and <dl>), emphasized or special text (<strong>, <code>, <abbr>, <blockquote>, for example), etc. Semantic markup is used appropriately.

heading: Description
value: Tables are used for tabular data and data cells are associated with their headers. Data table captions, if present, are associated to data tables.

heading: Description
value: Text labels are associated with form input elements. Related form elements are grouped with fieldset/legend. ARIA labelling may be used when standard HTML is insufficient.

heading: Description
value: The reading and navigation order (determined by code order) is logical and intuitive.

heading: Description
value: Instructions do not rely upon shape, size, or visual location (e.g., "Click the square icon to continue" or "Instructions are in the right-hand column").

heading: Description
value: Instructions do not rely upon sound (e.g., "A beeping sound indicates you may continue.").

heading: Description
value: Orientation of web content is not restricted to only portrait or landscape, unless a specific orientation is necessary.

heading: Description
value: Input fields that collect certain types of user information have an appropriate autocomplete attribute defined.

heading: Description
value: HTML5 regions or ARIA landmarks are used to identify page regions.

heading: Description
value: ARIA is used, where appropriate, to enhance HTML semantics to better identify the purpose of interface components.

heading: Description
value: Color is not used as the sole method of conveying content or distinguishing visual elements.

heading: Description
value: Color alone is not used to distinguish links from surrounding text unless the contrast ratio between the link and the surrounding text is at least 3:1 and an additional distinction (e.g., it becomes underlined) is provided when the link is hovered over and receives focus.

heading: Description
value: A mechanism is provided to stop, pause, mute, or adjust volume for audio that automatically plays on a page for more than 3 seconds.

heading: Description
value: Text and images of text have a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1.

heading: Description
value: Large text - at least 18 point (typically 24px) or 14 point (typically 18.66px) and bold - has a contrast ratio of at least 3:1.

heading: Description
value: The page is readable and functional when the page is zoomed to 200%. NOTE: 1.4.10 (below) introduces a much higher requirement for zoomed content.

heading: Description
value: If the same visual presentation can be made using text alone, an image is not used to present that text.

heading: Description
value: Text and images of text have a contrast ratio of at least 7:1.

heading: Description
value: Large text - at least 18 point (typically 24px) or 14 point (typically 18.66px) bold - has a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1.

heading: Description
value: Audio with speech has no or very low background noise so the speech is easily distinguished.

heading: Description
value:
Blocks of text over one sentence in length:
							
								Are no more than 80 characters wide.
								Are NOT fully justified (aligned to both the left and the right margins).
								Have adequate line spacing (at least 1/2 the height of the text) and paragraph spacing (1.5 times line spacing).
								Have a specified foreground and background color. These can be applied to specific elements or to the entire page using CSS (and thus inherited by all other elements).
								Do NOT require horizontal scrolling when the text size is doubled.

heading: Description
value: Are no more than 80 characters wide.

heading: Description
value: Are NOT fully justified (aligned to both the left and the right margins).

heading: Description
value: Have adequate line spacing (at least 1/2 the height of the text) and paragraph spacing (1.5 times line spacing).

heading: Description
value: Have a specified foreground and background color. These can be applied to specific elements or to the entire page using CSS (and thus inherited by all other elements).

heading: Description
value: Do NOT require horizontal scrolling when the text size is doubled.

heading: Description
value: Text is used within an image only for decoration (image does not convey content) OR when the information cannot be presented with text alone.

heading: Description
value:
No loss of content or functionality occurs and horizontal scrolling is avoided when content is presented at a width of 320 pixels.
							
								This requires responsive design for most web sites. This is best tested by setting the browser window to 1280 pixels wide and then zooming the page content to 400%.

heading: Description
value: This requires responsive design for most web sites. This is best tested by setting the browser window to 1280 pixels wide and then zooming the page content to 400%.

heading: Description
value: Content that requires horizontal scrolling, such as data tables, complex images (such as maps and charts), toolbars, etc. are exempted.

heading: Description
value: A contrast ratio of at least 3:1 is present for differentiating graphical objects (such as icons and components of charts or graphs) and author-customized interface components (such as buttons, form controls, and focus indicators/outlines).

heading: Description
value: At least 3:1 contrast must be provided in the various states (focus, hover, active, etc.) of author-customized interactive components.

heading: Description
value: No loss of content or functionality occurs when the user adapts paragraph spacing to 2 times the font size, text line height/spacing to 1.5 times the font size, word spacing to .16 times the font size, and letter spacing to .12 times the font size.

heading: Description
value: This is best supported by avoiding pixel height definitions for elements that contain text.

heading: Description
value:
When additional content is presented on hover or keyboard focus:
							
								The newly revealed content can be dismissed (generally via the Esc key) without moving the pointer or keyboard focus, unless the content presents an input error or does not obscure or interfere with other page content.
								The pointer can be moved to the new content without the content disappearing.
								The new content must remain visible until the pointer or keyboard focus is moved away from the triggering control, the new content is dismissed, or the new content is no longer relevant.

heading: Description
value: The newly revealed content can be dismissed (generally via the Esc key) without moving the pointer or keyboard focus, unless the content presents an input error or does not obscure or interfere with other page content.

heading: Description
value: The pointer can be moved to the new content without the content disappearing.

heading: Description
value: The new content must remain visible until the pointer or keyboard focus is moved away from the triggering control, the new content is dismissed, or the new content is no longer relevant.

heading: Description
value: All page functionality is available using the keyboard, unless the functionality cannot be accomplished in any known way using a keyboard (e.g., free hand drawing).

heading: Description
value: Page-specified shortcut keys and accesskeys (accesskey should typically be avoided) do not conflict with existing browser and screen reader shortcuts.

heading: Description
value: Keyboard focus is never locked or trapped at one particular page element. The user can navigate to and from all navigable page elements using only a keyboard.

heading: Description
value: All page functionality is available using the keyboard.

heading: Description
value: If a keyboard shortcut uses printable character keys, then the user must be able to disable the key command, change the defined key to a non-printable key (Ctrl, Alt, etc.), or only activate the shortcut when an associated interface component or button is focused.

heading: Description
value: If a page or application has a time limit, the user is given options to turn off, adjust, or extend that time limit. This is not a requirement for real-time events (e.g., an auction), where the time limit is absolutely required, or if the time limit is longer than 20 hours.

heading: Description
value: Automatically moving, blinking, or scrolling content (such as carousels, marquees, or animations) that lasts longer than 5 seconds can be paused, stopped, or hidden by the user.

heading: Description
value: Automatically updating content (e.g., a dynamically-updating news ticker, chat messages, etc.) can be paused, stopped, or hidden by the user or the user can manually control the timing of the updates.

heading: Description
value: The content and functionality have no time limits or constraints.

heading: Description
value: Interruptions (alerts, page updates, etc.) can be postponed or suppressed by the user.

heading: Description
value: If an authentication session expires, the user can re-authenticate and continue the activity without losing any data from the current page.

heading: Description
value: Users must be warned of any timeout that could result in data loss, unless the data is preserved for longer than 20 hours of user inactivity.

heading: Description
value: No page content flashes more than 3 times per second unless that flashing content is sufficiently small and the flashes are of low contrast and do not contain too much red. (See general flash and red flash thresholds)

heading: Description
value: No page content flashes more than 3 times per second.

heading: Description
value: Users can disable non-essential animation and movement that is triggered by user interaction.

heading: Description
value: A link is provided to skip navigation and other page elements that are repeated across web pages.

heading: Description
value: A proper heading structure and/or identification of page regions/landmarks may be considered a sufficient technique. Because navigating by headings or regions is not supported in most browsers, WebAIM recommends a "skip" link (in addition to headings and regions) to best support sighted keyboard users.

heading: Description
value: The web page has a descriptive and informative page title.

heading: Description
value: The navigation order of links, form elements, etc. is logical and intuitive.

heading: Description
value: The purpose of each link (or form image button or image map hotspot) can be determined from the link text alone, or from the link text and its context (e.g., surrounding text, list item, previous heading, or table headers).

heading: Description
value: Links (or form image buttons) with the same text that go to different locations are readily distinguishable.

heading: Description
value: Multiple ways are available to find other web pages on the site - at least two of: a list of related pages, table of contents, site map, site search, or list of all available web pages.

heading: Description
value: Page headings and labels for form and interactive controls are informative. Avoid duplicating heading (e.g., "More Details") or label text (e.g., "First Name") unless the structure provides adequate differentiation between them.

heading: Description
value: It is visually apparent which page element has the current keyboard focus (i.e., as you tab through the page, you can see where you are).

heading: Description
value: If a web page is part of a sequence of pages or within a complex site structure, an indication of the current page location is provided, for example, through breadcrumbs or specifying the current step in a sequence (e.g., "Step 2 of 5 - Shipping Address").

heading: Description
value: The purpose of each link (or form image button or image map hotspot) can be determined from the link text alone.

heading: Description
value: There are no links (or form image buttons) with the same text that go to different locations.

heading: Description
value: Beyond providing an overall document structure, individual sections of content are designated using headings, where appropriate.

heading: Description
value: If multipoint or path-based gestures (such as pinching, swiping, or dragging across the screen) are not essential to the functionality, then the functionality can also be performed with a single point activation (such as activating a button).

heading: Description
value: To help avoid inadvertent activation of controls, avoid non-essential down-event (e.g., onmousedown) activation when clicking, tapping, or long pressing the screen. Use onclick, onmouseup, or similar instead. If onmouseup (or similar) is used, you must provide a mechanism to abort or undo the action performed.

heading: Description
value: If an interface component (link, button, etc.) presents text (or images of text), the accessible name (label, alternative text, aria-label, etc.) for that component must include the visible text.

heading: Description
value: Functionality that is triggered by moving the device (such as shaking or panning a mobile device) or by user movement (such as waving to a camera) can be disabled and equivalent functionality is provided via standard controls like buttons.

heading: Description
value: Clickable targets are at least 44 by 44 pixels in size unless an alternative target of that size is provided, the target is inline (such as a link within a sentence), the target is not author-modified (such as a default checkbox), or the small target size is essential to the functionality.

heading: Description
value: Content does not restrict input to a specific modality, such as touch-only or keyboard-only, but must support alternative inputs (such as using a keyboard on a mobile device).

heading: Description
value: The language of the page is identified using the HTML lang attribute (e.g., <html lang="en">).

heading: Description
value: The language of page content that is in a different language is identified using the lang attribute (e.g., <blockquote lang="es">).

heading: Description
value: Words that may be ambiguous, unfamiliar, or used in a very specific way are defined through adjacent text, a definition list, a glossary, or other suitable method.

heading: Description
value: The meaning of an unfamiliar abbreviation is provided by expanding it the first time it is used, using the <abbr> element, or linking to a definition or glossary.

heading: Description
value: A more understandable alternative is provided for content that is more advanced than can be reasonably read by a person with roughly 9 years of primary education.

heading: Description
value: If the pronunciation of a word is vital to understanding that word, its pronunciation is provided immediately following the word or via a link or glossary.

heading: Description
value: When a page element receives focus, it does not result in a substantial change to the page, the spawning of a pop-up window, an additional change of keyboard focus, or any other change that could confuse or disorient the user.

heading: Description
value: When a user inputs information or interacts with a control, it does not result in a substantial change to the page, the spawning of a pop-up window, an additional change of keyboard focus, or any other change that could confuse or disorient the user unless the user is informed of the change ahead of time.

heading: Description
value: Navigation links that are repeated on web pages do not change order when navigating through the site.

heading: Description
value: Elements that have the same functionality across multiple web pages are consistently identified. For example, a search box at the top of the site should always be labeled the same way.

heading: Description
value: Substantial changes to the page, the spawning of pop-up windows, uncontrolled changes of keyboard focus, or any other change that could confuse or disorient the user must be initiated by the user. Alternatively, the user is provided an option to disable such changes.

heading: Description
value: Required form elements or form elements that require a specific format, value, or length provide this information within the element's label.

heading: Description
value: Form validation errors are efficient, intuitive, and accessible. The error is clearly identified, quick access to the problematic element is provided, and the user can easily fix the error and resubmit the form.

heading: Description
value: Sufficient labels, cues, and instructions for required interactive elements are provided via instructions, examples, properly positioned form labels, and/or fieldsets/legends.

heading: Description
value: If an input error is detected (via client-side or server-side validation), suggestions are provided for fixing the input in a timely and accessible manner.

heading: Description
value: If the user can change or delete legal, financial, or test data, the changes/deletions can be reversed, verified, or confirmed.

heading: Description
value: Instructions and cues are provided in context to help in form completion and submission.

heading: Description
value: If the user can submit information, the submission is reversible, verified, or confirmed.

heading: Description
value: Significant HTML/XHTML validation/parsing errors are avoided. Check at http://validator.w3.org/

heading: Description
value: Markup is used in a way that facilitates accessibility. This includes following the HTML/XHTML specifications and using forms, form labels, frame titles, etc. appropriately.

heading: Description
value: ARIA is used appropriately to enhance accessibility when HTML is not sufficient.

heading: Description
value: If an important status message is presented and focus is not set to that message, the message must be announced to screen reader users, typically via an ARIA alert or live region.
